get.passphrase.description:
Many operations require SSH access, and the private key is supplied by an SSH agent.  The SSH agent cannot load the private key because it is protected by a passphrase. Please provide this SSH passphrase in order to load the private key into the SSH agent.
In the event that the ardana service and the SSH agent are restarted while logged into the CLM Admin Console, operations that require the SSH key will fail until you logout and log back in and enter the SSH passphrase here.
get.passphrase.invalid: SSH passphrase provided is incorrect. Please provide the correct SSH passphrase.
get.passphrase.error:
Unable to use the provided SSH passphrase: {0}.
Please correct the problem and try again.

common.encryptkey.description: The operation you are about to perform runs a playbook that requires the encryption key. If the encryption key provided is incorrect the playbook will fail and the browser window will need to be refreshed in order to re-enter the encryption key.

server.import.server.confirm:
The imported servers will overwrite previously imported servers if they have the same ID.
 If imported servers have the same ID as the manually added servers or discovered servers, servers with duplicate ID could show up. Servers that have been assigned a role and have duplicate ID will be highlighted in red. You can edit the server to update the ID.

 Do you still want to import servers?
server.import.server.confirm.limit.confl:
The imported servers without a role will overwrite previously imported servers without a role if they have the same ID.
 If imported servers have the same ID as the manually added servers or discovered servers, servers with duplicate ID could show up.
 Servers with roles that don't belong to the target roles will be ignored. Servers that have been assigned a role and have a duplicate ID, or IP address or MAC address or IPMI address will be ignored. 

 Do you still want to import servers?

model.summary.role.description.CONTROLLE:
Controller nodes run the cloud control plane services. They host Keystone, Horizon, Glance, and other essential cloud services in a single host.

  Example of services that run on a controller node:
    - apache2
    - cinder-api
    - cinder-scheduler
    - glance-api
    - glance-registry
    - heat-api
    - heat-api-cfn
    - heat-api-cloudwatch
    - heat-engine
    - neutron-dhcp-agent
    - neutron-metadata-agent
    - neutron-openvswitch-agent
    - neutron-server
    - neutron-vpn-agent
    - nova-api
    - nova-conductor
    - nova-consoleauth
    - nova-scheduler
    - nova-novncproxy
model.summary.role.description.COMPUTE-R:
Compute nodes provide compute services like nova-compute. They are hypervisors where workloads run.

  Example of services that run on Compute node:
    - neutron-l3-agent
    - neutron-lbaasv2-agent
    - neutron-metadata-agent
    - neutron-openvswitch-agent
    - nova-compute
model.summary.role.description.MTRMON-RO:
Metering and Monitoring nodes run the cloud services for metering and monitoring such as celiometer, monasca, and logging.

  Examples of services that run on a Metering and Monitoring node:
    - ntp-client
    - ceilometer-api
    - ceilometer-polling
    - ceilometer-agent-notification
    - ceilometer-common
    - ceilometer-client
    - cassandra
    - kafka
    - spark
    - logging-server
    - apache2
    - storm
    - monasca-api
    - monasca-persister
    - monasca-notifier
    - monasca-threshold
    - monasca-client
    - monasca-transform
    - zookeeper
    - freezer-api
model.summary.role.description.DBMQ-ROLE:
Database and Message Queue nodes run clustered MariaDB and RabbitMQ services to support the cloud infrastructure.

  Examples of services that run on a Database and Message Queue node:
    - ntp-client
    - mysql
    - rabbitmq
model.summary.role.description.SWOBJ-ROL:
Swift Object nodes run the Swift Object service.

  Examples of services that run on a Swift Object node:
    - ntp-client
    - swift-object
model.summary.role.description.CORE-ROLE:
Core nodes run core cloud services like keystone, nova api, glance api, neutron api, horizon, heat, etc..

  Examples of services that run on a Core node:
    - lifecycle-manager
    - tempest
    - apache2
    - keystone-api
    - cinder-api
    - cinder-scheduler
    - cinder-volume
    - cinder-backup
    - cinder-client
    - keystone-client
    - glance-api
    - glance-registry
    - glance-client
    - horizon
    - heat-api
    - heat-api-cfn
    - heat-api-cloudwatch
    - heat-engine
    - heat-client
    - ip-cluster
    - memcached
    - openstack-client
    - nova-api
    - nova-scheduler
    - nova-conductor
    - nova-console-auth
    - nova-novncproxy
    - nova-client
    - neutron-server
    - neutron-ml2-plugin
    - neutron-client
    - octavia-api
    - octavia-health-manager
    - ntp-server
    - ops-console-web
    - ops-console-monitor
    - barbican-api
    - barbican-client
    - barbican-worker
    - designate-api
    - designate-central
    - designate-pool-manager
    - designate-zone-manager
    - designate-mdns
    - designate-client
    - bind
    - magnum-api
    - magnum-conductor
model.summary.role.description.SWPAC-ROL:
Swift PAC nodes runs the Swift Proxy, Account, and Container services.

  Examples of services that run on a Swift PAC node:
    - ntp-client
    - swift-proxy
    - swift-account
    - swift-container
    - swift-ring-builder
    - swift-client
model.summary.role.description.NEUTRON-R:
Neutron nodes run Neutron cloud services like VPN (L3), DHCP, Metadata and OpenVswitch agents.

  Examples of services that run on a Neutron node:
    - ntp-client
    - neutron-vpn-agent
    - neutron-dhcp-agent
    - neutron-metadata-agent
    - neutron-openvswitch-agent
model.summary.role.description.ESX-COMPU:
ESX compute nodes are VM Appliances which run on ESX hypervisors. They provide nova proxy services for integrating Vmware ESX hypervisors into the cloud.

  Example of services that run on an ESX compute node:
    - nova-proxy
model.summary.role.description.OVSVAPP-R:
OVSvAPP nodes are VM Appliances running on ESX hypervisors which provide network connectivity to VMs running on ESX hypervisors.

  Example of services that run on an OVSvAPP node:
    - neutron_ovsvapp_agent
    - openvswitch
model.summary.role.description.IRONIC-CO:
Ironic compute nodes are compute nodes created via bare metal provisioning.

  Example of services that run on an Ironic compute node:
    - neutron-l3-agent
    - neutron-lbaasv2-agent
    - neutron-metadata-agent
    - neutron-openvswitch-agent
    - nova-compute
model.summary.role.description.NOT_FOUND: These user-generated nodes are custom components created for specific purposes.

replace.server.compute.notreachable.inst:
The compute host {0} with IP {1} is not reachable and failed to determine if the compute host has instances ({2}). 
If you still want to continue the replacement process, be aware that the replacement process will try to evacuate instances from the old compute host. 
Make sure the compute hosts are configured with block storage or shared storage. 

 Do you still want to proceed?

server.deploy.failure.cancel.confirm:
Canceling could potentially leave the cloud deployment in a bad state. It will close the window, and any error messages will no longer be available to view.

Proceed with cancellation?
server.addserver.failure.prep.cancel.con:
Canceling will close the window, and any error messages will no longer be available to view. 

The following steps need to be performed manually on the cloud deployer before clicking Yes to cancel... 
1. cd ~/openstack/my_cloud/definition/data 
2. Remove the new compute server(s) from servers.yml 
3. git commit -a -m 'commit message' 
4. cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible 
5. ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml 
6. ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml  

 If the Add Server page continues to display the removed servers, refresh the page using the web browser. To retry deployment, re-add the servers to the appropriate role, and click the "Deploy" button. 

Proceed with cancellation?
server.addserver.failure.add.cancel.conf:
Canceling could potentially leave the process of adding the new compute server(s) in a bad state. It will close the window, and any error messages will no longer be available to view. 

Proceed with cancellation?
server.addserver.installos.cancel.confir:
This will cancel the OS installation for the new compute server(s).  

Proceed with cancellation?
server.replace.compute.osinstall.failure:
Canceling will close the window and any error messages will no longer be available to view. 
After canceling, the new and undeployed compute server {0} will show up in the Server Summary page. Navigate to the Add Server page to unassign it from its role before attempting to replace server {1} again  

Proceed with cancellation?
server.replace.compute.failure.prepadd.c:
Canceling will close the window, and any error messages will no longer be available to view. 

The following steps need to be performed manually on the cloud deployer before clicking Yes to cancel... 
1. cd ~/openstack/my_cloud/definition/data 
2. Remove the new compute server {0} from servers.yml 
3. git commit -a -m 'commit message' 
4. cd ~/openstack/ardana/ansible 
5. ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml 
6. ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml  

 If the Summary page continues to display the removed server, refresh the page using the web browser.  

Proceed with cancellation?
server.replace.compute.failure.add.cance:
Canceling could potentially leave the process of adding the new compute server {0} in a bad state. It will close the window, and any error messages will no longer be available to view.
